content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Nicholas Aguirre: Well, I was born in Oregon, in a small town called Pacific, and I've lived in Eugene ever since I was 16. My parents are both pretty educated—my dad has a bachelor's degree, and my mom has a graduate degree. We were never really poor, but we weren't rolling in money either. I grew up in a typical middle-class household, with both parents working. My mom was a teacher, and my dad worked in engineering. I never really had a lot of financial stress, which I think helped me focus on school. I wasn't the best student, but I did okay in high school. I didn't go to college because I wanted to start working and saving money. I've been working part-time at a local bookstore ever since I graduated. I'm not really into politics, but I lean a bit conservative, mostly because I value personal responsibility and individual freedom. I don't have any kids, and I've never been married. I'm pretty independent, and I like keeping things simple. I speak a little Spanish from my mom's side of the family, but I don't use it much anymore. I don't really follow any religion, and I've never served in the military. Life hasn't been too dramatic, but I'm content with where I am.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Nicholas Aguirre: Hmm, thinking about it, there was one moment that really shaped my path. I was about 18, right after I graduated high school. I had the option to go to community college, which my mom really encouraged me to do. She thought it would be a good way to get my feet wet with higher education before committing to a four-year program. But I was already working part-time at the bookstore, and I was saving up for a used car so I could move out on my own. I didn't want to take on more debt or spend another year in school when I felt like I was already gaining real experience. I remember talking to my dad about it, and he said something like, 'If you're not sure, it's better to take the time to figure it out than to rush into something you don't want.' That made me think. I ended up taking a year off, working full-time, and saving up enough to move into my own apartment. That decision gave me a sense of independence I wouldn't have had otherwise. I still wish I had gone to college, but I think I needed that time to grow on my own first. It taught me a lot about responsibility and making decisions based on what I wanted, not just what others expected.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Nicholas Aguirre: I think it was a conscious choice, even if it wasn't clear at the time. I didn't just wake up one day and decide to take a year off—I weighed the options, talked it through with my parents, and thought about what I wanted for myself. I didn't want to feel like I was just going through the motions in college if I wasn't sure I wanted to be there. I wanted to be in control of my own path, even if it meant taking a different route than what was expected. I guess I've always believed that life is about making choices that align with who you are, not just following what others think you should do.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Nicholas Aguirre: I think if I had talked to someone who could offer a different perspective, maybe it would have helped. I know my parents meant well, but they both came from a place of wanting the best for me, which sometimes made it hard for me to voice my own doubts. I wish I had spoken to a counselor or someone who worked with young adults making similar decisions. I think they could have helped me see the long-term implications of my choice more clearly. But honestly, I don't know if anyone could have changed my mind. I was pretty set on wanting to be independent, and I think that desire was stronger than any advice I might have gotten from someone else.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Nicholas Aguirre: I don't have a partner or any children right now. My family is pretty small—just my parents and me. My mom and dad are still in Eugene, and we keep in touch, though we don't see each other as often as I'd like. My mom still teaches at the same high school she's been at for years, and my dad is retired now, which gives him more time to spend on his hobbies, like woodworking and gardening. I visit them whenever I can, usually on weekends or holidays. I value family, but I also enjoy my independence. I don't see myself getting married anytime soon, and I'm not sure if I want kids. I think I want to focus on building a stable life for myself first—maybe save up more, travel a bit, and see where things go. I don't want to rush into anything, you know?

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by choices I made, especially that one at 18 when I decided not to go to college. It wasn't an easy decision, but it felt right at the time. I think I was trying to find my own path instead of just following what others expected. I'm proud of the independence I've built since then, even if I sometimes wonder what might have been if I had taken a different route. Talking about my family and my values made me realize how much I appreciate the support I've had, even if I didn't always express it clearly. I don't know where I'm headed next, but I feel good about where I am now.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Nicholas Aguirre: My immediate family is just my parents and me. I don't have any siblings, which I think is pretty common in our family—my parents are both first-generation in a lot of ways, so they didn't have a lot of siblings themselves. I always felt like I had a close relationship with both of them, even if we didn't always agree on things. My mom was always the one who pushed me to think about my future, while my dad was more about giving me space to figure things out on my own. I think that balance helped me a lot. I don't have any other family members living nearby, but I do have a few cousins on my mom's side who live in California. We don't talk too often, but when we do, it's always nice to catch up. I guess I'm pretty lucky to have a family that supports me, even if we don't always see eye to eye.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Nicholas Aguirre: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with. One of them, Jordan, works at the same bookstore I do, and we've been friends for years. We've been through a lot together—like figuring out our careers, dealing with the ups and downs of part-time jobs, and just trying to find our way in life. I also have a couple of friends from the community center where I sometimes volunteer. They're all pretty laid-back, like me, and we share a lot of the same values—like independence and not wanting to be tied down by things we don't need. I don't have any romantic partners right now, and honestly, I don't think I'm in a rush for that. I like having my own space and being able to focus on my goals without any distractions. I think relationships are important, but I also think it's okay to take your time and not force anything. I'm happy with the people I have in my life, even if it's not the most traditional setup.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Nicholas Aguirre: I live in a pretty quiet neighborhood on the east side of Eugene, just a few blocks from the river. It's a mix of older homes and some newer apartments, and there's a lot of green space around here. I rent a small one-bedroom apartment from an older couple who own a few properties in the area. They're pretty friendly, and I've gotten to know them a bit over the years. The neighborhood isn't too busy, which I like—it gives me a sense of peace and quiet that I need after working at the bookstore. There's a small park nearby where I like to take walks, and a few local shops and cafes that I go to on the weekends. It's not the most exciting place in the world, but it's comfortable and familiar. I think that's what I need right now—something stable and predictable, without too many surprises. I don't know if I'll ever move out of the area, but for now, I'm happy with where I am.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Nicholas Aguirre: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. The neighborhood is quiet, and there's a real sense of community. I know most of the people who live around here, and they all seem to look out for each other. I've never had any issues with crime or anything like that. It's not the kind of place where you have to lock your doors at night or worry about walking home after work. I think that sense of safety is part of why I've stayed here for so long. It's not just about the physical safety, either—it's the feeling that you belong, that you're part of something bigger. I don't know if I'd feel that same comfort in a bigger city, but for now, this feels like the right place for me.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Nicholas Aguirre: Living here has had its ups and downs, like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the peace of mind—it's a place where I can wake up without worrying about traffic, noise, or the fast pace of city life. I like that I can walk to the park, grab a coffee from the corner shop, and just enjoy the quiet. But there are downs too. Sometimes I feel like I'm stuck in a routine, doing the same thing every day. I work at the bookstore, come home, maybe read a bit, and that's it. I know some people might find that boring, but I think it's what I need right now. I don't want to rush into something bigger or more complicated when I'm still figuring out what I want. I guess I'm just in a phase where I'm content with simplicity, even if it doesn't feel like the most exciting path. I hope that changes someday, but for now, I'm okay with where I am.

Going through those questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my current life is built on the foundation of the people and places I've known for a long time. I've always valued independence, but I also see how much my parents have shaped me, even if I didn't always agree with them. My neighborhood gives me a sense of stability, and I think that's something I need right now. I don't know where I'm headed in the future, but I feel grounded in the present. It's comforting to know that I have a family that supports me, even if we don't always see eye to eye, and a community that feels like home.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Nicholas Aguirre: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, honestly. I work part-time at the bookstore, usually four days a week—Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays, and Sundays. The hours are pretty flexible, which I appreciate. On the days I work, I usually wake up around 8 or 9, have a quick breakfast, and head into the store. The rest of the day is pretty slow-paced—helping customers find books, organizing shelves, and sometimes just reading a bit in the back. After work, I like to take a walk near the river or grab a bite to eat at one of the little cafes nearby. On the days I don't work, I tend to sleep in a bit more, read, or maybe do some light chores around the apartment. I also try to volunteer at the community center a couple of times a week, mostly helping out with events or just chatting with people. It's not the most exciting schedule, but it's steady and gives me time to think, reflect, and just be by myself. I guess I'm in a phase where I'm okay with the routine—it keeps me grounded, even if it doesn't feel like it's pushing me forward in any big way.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Nicholas Aguirre: I work part-time at a local bookstore, which is actually the same one I started at right after high school. I usually work Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays, and Sundays, mostly in the afternoon, which gives me a good balance between work and personal time. The job isn't too demanding, but I enjoy it because I get to be around books and meet people who share my love for reading. It's a small store, so I know most of the regular customers by name, and that makes the experience more personal. I also help out with organizing events sometimes, like book clubs or author readings, which I find pretty rewarding. It's not a high-paying job, but it's steady, and I like the flexibility it offers. I can take days off when I need to, and I don't have to deal with the stress of a full-time schedule. It's not the kind of job that will make me rich, but it's enough to cover my expenses and give me some savings. I think I'm okay with that for now—I don't need more than what I have.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Nicholas Aguirre: Outside of work and the routine stuff, I also try to keep up with some personal projects. I've always been interested in photography, so I like to take my camera out on weekends and shoot around the neighborhood or by the river. It's a way for me to capture the little things I notice—like the way the light hits the water in the morning or the colors of the leaves in the fall. I don't really take it seriously, but it's something that gives me a creative outlet. I also like to cook on the weekends, mostly simple meals—paninis, soups, things like that. I don't have a lot of fancy equipment, but I enjoy experimenting with recipes and making something from scratch. It's another way to break up the routine and feel like I'm doing something meaningful, even if it's just for myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Nicholas Aguirre: Well, the biggest change recently has been that I started taking evening classes at the community college, just a few nights a week. It's been a bit of a shift for me, going back to a structured learning environment after so long. I've been taking some basic courses in literature and history, mostly because I enjoy reading and I wanted to challenge myself a little. It's not like going back to college full-time, but it's given me a new sense of purpose. I think I've been feeling a bit restless lately, like I want to keep learning even if I'm not sure where it will take me. It's been a nice balance between my routine and something new. I'm still working the same hours at the bookstore, but now I have a few more hours each week dedicated to something that feels more like growth. I don't know if I'll end up going for a degree or not, but for now, it's just about keeping my mind active and exploring options.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Nicholas Aguirre: I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them. But I can imagine what it might be like if I did. I think I'd want them to have a balance between school, family time, and some kind of creative outlet—maybe something like art or music, just like I enjoy photography. I'd also want them to have time to be kids, to play outside, and to explore their interests without too much pressure. I guess I'd be the kind of parent who encourages independence but also provides a safe, stable environment. I don't know if I'd push them toward college or a career right away—I think I'd want them to figure out what they want on their own, just like I did. It's funny, thinking about it, because I never really had kids growing up, but I've always admired the people who do. They have this incredible ability to shape lives and create something beautiful, even if it's not always easy.

Going through the questions about my neighborhood, daily routine, and job made me realize how much my life has settled into a rhythm that feels safe and familiar. I've always valued independence, and living in a quiet neighborhood, working at the bookstore, and keeping things simple aligns with that. But there's also a part of me that feels like I'm standing still, not moving forward in the way I used to imagine. Taking those evening classes at the community college was a small step toward change, something that gives me a sense of growth without overwhelming me. I don't know where this will lead, but it's comforting to know that I can still learn and explore, even if I'm not following the traditional path. I think I'm in a place where I need stability, but I also want to keep my options open. It's a balance I'm still figuring out, but for now, I'm okay with where I am.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Nicholas Aguirre: As for my health, I'd say I'm pretty average. I don't have any major issues, but I've been trying to take better care of myself lately. I used to skip meals when I was working long hours or forget to exercise altogether, but I've started making an effort to eat more regularly and go for walks by the river a few times a week. I've also been sleeping better, which helps a lot with my mood and energy levels. I don't really go to the doctor much unless something feels off, but I've been more proactive about checking in with myself. I think part of that has to do with getting older and realizing that taking care of your body is just as important as taking care of your mind. I don't have any chronic conditions or serious illnesses, but I do get the occasional cold or sore throat, like everyone else. I guess I'm in a good place health-wise—no major concerns, just trying to stay on top of the little things so I can keep doing the things I enjoy, like reading, walking, and taking those evening classes.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Nicholas Aguirre: I think what makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine that includes some physical activity, even if it's just walking around the neighborhood or taking the stairs instead of the elevator. I also find that eating more mindfully—like actually sitting down to eat instead of grabbing something on the go—helps me feel better overall. What makes it harder is when I get caught up in work or my own thoughts and forget to take care of myself. There are days when I just want to stay in bed or skip a walk because I feel tired or unmotivated. But I've learned that even small things, like drinking more water or stretching for a few minutes, can make a difference. I guess it's about balance—knowing that I don't have to be perfect, just consistent in trying to take care of myself.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Nicholas Aguirre: Actually, nothing major has happened in the past two years related to my health. I've been pretty lucky in that regard. I did have a minor knee injury a while back from playing soccer with some friends, but it was nothing serious—just a sprain that healed on its own after a few weeks. I've also been dealing with some occasional back pain, probably from sitting too long at the bookstore or not stretching enough. I've started doing some light yoga to help with that, which has been helpful. Other than that, I haven't had any big medical diagnoses or issues. I think the biggest change has been me becoming more aware of how my lifestyle affects my body, and I've made a conscious effort to take better care of myself. It's not perfect, but I feel like I'm on the right track.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Nicholas Aguirre: Honestly, I don't think my health has ever really gotten in the way of my work or anything else I do. Even when I had that knee sprain a while back, it didn't stop me from working or going about my day—it just made me more aware of how important it is to take care of my body. I've never had anything that required me to take time off or change my routine in a big way. I guess that's one of the benefits of not having a high-stress job or a lot of responsibilities—it gives me the flexibility to slow down and recover when I need to. I also don't have any chronic conditions that would make it hard to care for someone else, which I think is something to be grateful for. I know a lot of people have to deal with health issues that limit their ability to work or take care of their families, and I feel lucky that I haven't had to face that. It makes me appreciate the little things more, like being able to walk without pain or having the energy to do the things I enjoy.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Nicholas Aguirre: Over the past year, I've been feeling pretty stable, but there's been a quiet kind of growth happening beneath the surface. I think I've been more reflective lately, maybe because I've been taking those evening classes and it's made me think about things I hadn't considered before. I've started reading more deeply, not just for pleasure but for understanding—like diving into historical texts or literature that challenges my perspective. It's given me a sense of purpose that I didn't realize I was missing. At the same time, I've been trying to be more present in my daily life, whether it's enjoying the simple act of making a meal or taking a walk by the river and really noticing the details around me. I don't know if I'm happier, but I feel more grounded. There have been moments of doubt, of course—times when I wonder if I'm stuck or if I'm just avoiding bigger decisions. But overall, I think I'm in a good place. I'm learning to accept that life doesn't have to be dramatic to be meaningful, and I'm okay with that for now.

Going through the questions about my recent changes and health made me realize how much I've been trying to find balance in my life. Taking evening classes at the community college was a small but meaningful step toward growth, and it reminded me that learning doesn't have to be a big, dramatic event—it can be something simple, like showing up a few nights a week and engaging with new ideas. At the same time, thinking about my health made me reflect on how much I've been trying to take care of myself, even in small ways. It's not always easy, especially when life feels routine or when I'm not in the mood to move or eat properly, but I've come to accept that consistency matters more than perfection. I'm not sure where this all leads, but I feel like I'm on a path that's more intentional now, even if it's not the one I expected.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Nicholas Aguirre: I don't think I've ever struggled with depression or anxiety in a way that really impacted my daily life. There have been moments of feeling stuck or uncertain, especially when I was younger and trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my life. But I've always managed to push through by focusing on the things I enjoy—like reading, walking, or just having a quiet evening at home. I think part of it is that I've never had a lot of pressure on me, either from work or from other people. I don't have a high-stress job, and I've never been in a situation where I felt like I had to perform or meet someone else's expectations. That said, I've definitely had days where I felt down or unmotivated, but I've always found ways to get back on track. I think I've learned to be kind to myself and not beat myself up over small things. I don't know if that's enough to call it mental health, but I feel like I've been pretty resilient overall.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Nicholas Aguirre: My family has been pretty steady through all of this, which I think is one of the reasons I've been able to find my own path without too much pressure. My mom has always been supportive, even when she didn't fully understand my decision to take a break from school. She's the kind of person who believes in education, so I think she worried I was missing out on something important. But she's never pushed me too hard—she just let me know she was there if I ever wanted to talk. My dad, on the other hand, has always been more about giving me space. He's the kind of person who believes in learning through experience, so he never really questioned my choice. He just said, 'If you're doing what you think is right, then I support you.' That kind of balance between my mom's encouragement and my dad's trust has been really important for me. I think they've both seen me grow over the years, even if they don't always agree with the direction I'm taking. I feel lucky to have parents who care about me but also respect my independence. They've never made me feel like I had to follow a certain path, and I think that's given me the freedom to figure things out on my own.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Nicholas Aguirre: I don't really think religion or spirituality has played a big role in my life, not in the way it does for some people. I grew up in a household where it wasn't really discussed much—my parents aren't religious, and I never really felt the need to explore it myself. I think I've always been more of a person who finds meaning in the everyday things, like the quiet moments, the beauty in nature, or the connections I have with the people around me. I don't believe in a higher power or any kind of organized faith, but I do believe in being kind, responsible, and living with integrity. I guess I see spirituality more as a personal thing, something that comes from within rather than from a book or a church. I don't feel like I'm missing out on anything by not having a religion—I feel like I have my own way of making sense of the world, and that's enough for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Nicholas Aguirre: I don't really use social media much, to be honest. I know a lot of people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through Instagram or Facebook, but I've never felt the need to be part of that. I think it's more of a habit for some people, something they do to stay connected or pass the time. For me, I prefer to keep things simple—like reading a book, taking a walk, or just sitting in my apartment and thinking. I do have a few friends who I talk to online, mostly from high school, but I don't follow a lot of people or post anything regularly. I guess I just don't see the point in trying to keep up with everyone else's lives when I'm more interested in my own. I know it might sound a bit old-fashioned, but I feel like I'm missing out on something if I'm always looking at my phone instead of being present in the moment. I don't mind being a bit off the grid—it gives me more time to focus on what I actually enjoy.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Nicholas Aguirre: Honestly, I don't think I've ever relied on social media for support, emotional or otherwise. I know it's a common thing for people to turn to online communities when they're going through something tough, but I've always found comfort in the people I know in real life—my parents, my friends, the folks at the bookstore. I think I've always been more of a face-to-face kind of person. When I'm struggling with something, I'd rather talk to someone in person than scroll through a bunch of posts that might not even be relevant to what I'm going through. I guess I just don't see the point in adding more noise to my life when I already have enough going on. I'm not saying social media is bad—I just don't need it to feel supported. I've always believed that real connections, even if they're quiet or simple, are the ones that matter most.

Going through the questions about my health and recent feelings made me realize how much I've been trying to take care of myself, even in small ways. I've always valued independence, but I'm starting to see that taking care of my body and mind is just as important as anything else. I don't have any major health issues, but I've been making an effort to eat better, move more, and be more present in my daily life. It's not always easy, especially when I'm feeling stuck or unmotivated, but I've come to accept that consistency matters more than perfection. I've also been thinking more about my mental state—how I've managed to avoid serious struggles with depression or anxiety, even when I've felt uncertain about my path. I think it's because I've always had the freedom to make my own choices, without too much pressure from others. My family has been a big part of that, giving me the space to grow on my own terms. I don't know where I'm headed next, but I feel more grounded now than I have in a long time. I'm learning to accept that life doesn't have to be dramatic to be meaningful, and I'm okay with that for now.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Nicholas Aguirre: I think my stress levels have been pretty low lately, which is something I'm actually pretty grateful for. I used to worry a lot more about the future—like, what if I never find a real career or end up stuck in this part-time job forever? But now, I feel like I've come to terms with the fact that life doesn't have to follow a strict timeline. I've been using a few different coping strategies to stay balanced. One of them is reading—especially fiction. It helps me step out of my own head and into someone else's world, which can be really calming. I also try to stay active, even if it's just a short walk or some light stretching. And I've been talking more with my friends, even if it's just about small things. I think the biggest change for me has been learning to accept uncertainty instead of fighting against it. I don't know where I'm headed next, but I feel more at peace with not knowing than I ever have before.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Nicholas Aguirre: My biggest expenses last month were rent, groceries, and a few small bills like internet and phone service. Rent is the biggest chunk—my apartment is pretty modest, but it's in a good location, and I value the peace and quiet it offers. Groceries can add up, especially when I'm cooking more at home these days instead of eating out. I also set aside a little money each month for books, since that's a passion of mine, and I like supporting local authors or independent publishers whenever I can. I don't have a lot of debt, which helps, and I've been trying to save a bit each month in case I want to travel or take more classes in the future. It's not a huge budget, but it works for me. I don't need much to be happy, and I think that's part of why I've been able to stay content with my current situation.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Nicholas Aguirre: I'd say my household spending last month was around $1,800, give or take a bit. That's pretty much in line with what I usually spend each month. Rent takes up about $900, which is a big chunk, but it's manageable. Groceries come to around $400, and I try to be careful with that by buying in bulk and cooking at home. I also spend about $100 on utilities—electricity, water, and internet. Then there's another $100 or so for books and other small purchases, like coffee or a few meals out on the weekends. I've been trying to save a little each month, so I set aside about $100 for savings or unexpected expenses. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep me going without too much stress. I don't need much to be happy, and I think that's part of why I've been able to stay content with my current situation.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Nicholas Aguirre: We rent our home. I live in a small one-bedroom apartment on the east side of Eugene, just a few blocks from the river. It's not much, but it's comfortable and has everything I need. The rent is pretty reasonable for the area, and the landlord is a retired couple who own a few properties. They're pretty laid-back and don't bother me too much as long as I pay on time and keep the place in decent shape. I like the fact that I don't have a mortgage or any big financial obligations tied to a house—I think that gives me more freedom to make choices without worrying about long-term commitments. Renting also means I can move if I ever feel like I need a change, which is something I value. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, especially with the way the real estate market is these days. For now, this setup works for me.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Nicholas Aguirre: Over the past year, my bills have stayed pretty consistent, but there have been a few small fluctuations. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill goes up a bit, and I've noticed that my electricity usage increases when I'm using the space heater more. On the flip side, in the summer, I use less heating but end up spending a little more on groceries because I tend to buy more fresh produce and eat more meals at home. There's also the holiday season, which brings a few extra expenses—like a small gift for my parents or a nice dinner out with friends. I try to budget for those things in advance, so it doesn't throw me off too much. Overall, I've found that my expenses don't vary too wildly, which helps me feel more in control of my finances. I don't mind the small changes, as long as I'm not getting caught off guard by them.

Going through the questions about my family and my mental health made me realize how much my parents have been a constant presence in my life, even if we don't always agree on things. Their support has given me the freedom to make my own choices without too much pressure, which I think has been really important for my sense of independence. I also think about how I don't rely on social media or online communities for emotional support, which feels like a good thing. I've always found comfort in real, face-to-face connections, and I think that's helped me stay grounded even when I've felt uncertain about my path. I don't have any major health issues, but I've been trying to take better care of myself in small ways—like eating more regularly, walking more, and being more present in my daily life. It's not always easy, but I've come to accept that consistency matters more than perfection. I feel like I'm on a path that's more intentional now, even if it's not the one I expected.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Nicholas Aguirre: I do save, though not in a traditional way. I have a small savings account, but I also keep a portion of my money in cash, just in case. I think it's more of a habit from growing up—my parents always emphasized the importance of having some money set aside for emergencies. I try to save about $100 a month, which doesn't sound like much, but over time it adds up. I also have a few jars at home labeled for different things—like 'travel fund,' 'book purchases,' and 'unexpected expenses.' It's a simple system, but it helps me feel more in control of my finances. I don't have any big goals right now, like buying a house or starting a business, so saving isn't about a specific future purchase for me. It's more about having a little cushion, just in case life throws something unexpected my way. I think that's enough for now—being prepared without being too rigid about it.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Nicholas Aguirre: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing rather than a big purchase like a home. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, and honestly, I don't know if I'd even want one. I like the freedom that comes with renting—being able to move if I need to, not having the weight of a mortgage or property taxes. My savings are more about having a little buffer, just in case something unexpected comes up. Like, if I need to take a few days off work to handle a personal matter, or if I want to take a spontaneous trip somewhere without having to worry about money. I don't have any grand plans, but I do want to feel secure enough to make small choices without stress. It's not a lot, but it gives me peace of mind, and I think that's enough for now.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Nicholas Aguirre: My occupation is working part-time at a local bookstore, which has been my main source of income for the past few years. The work itself is pretty varied—I spend a lot of time helping customers find books, organizing the shelves, and keeping the store tidy. I also assist with events like book clubs and author readings, which I find really rewarding because it brings people together over something they all love—reading. One of the most important parts of my job is being friendly and approachable. I've gotten to know a lot of regulars by name, and that personal connection makes the job feel more meaningful. I also enjoy the quiet moments, like when I'm in the back of the store reading a book or just sitting and thinking. It's not a high-pressure job, but it gives me a sense of purpose and allows me to stay connected to something I'm passionate about. I think that's why I've stayed there for so long—it's not just about the money, but about the experience and the people I meet along the way.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Nicholas Aguirre: I usually work around 20 hours a week, spread out over four days—Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays, and Sundays. The hours are pretty flexible, which I really appreciate. I usually start around 2 p.m. and finish up by 8 or 9 p.m., depending on how busy the store is. Some days are slower, and I can wrap up earlier, while other days, especially on weekends, we get a lot of customers, and I stay later. I like that I can adjust my schedule a bit based on what's needed. It gives me the freedom to have weekends mostly to myself, which I value a lot. I don't need a lot of money to be happy, and this schedule allows me to keep things balanced between work, my personal time, and the evening classes I've been taking. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover my expenses and give me some savings, which I think is pretty good for where I am in life right now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Nicholas Aguirre: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on keeping things simple, and working part-time at the bookstore has been enough for me. I did consider taking on a second job for a while, maybe something like delivering groceries or working at a café on weekends, but I realized I needed time to myself to read, think, and just be present. I don't want to feel like I'm constantly running from one task to another. The bookstore gives me a steady income, and it's flexible enough that I can take days off when I need to. Plus, I've been taking those evening classes at the community college, and I want to make sure I can keep up with that without burning myself out. I think having one job that I enjoy, combined with some personal time and learning, is the right balance for me right now.

Going through the interview questions about my stress levels, emotional coping strategies, and my family's support made me realize how much I've been relying on simple, consistent habits to stay grounded. I used to worry a lot about the future—what if I never find a real career or end up stuck in this part-time job forever? But now, I feel like I've come to terms with the fact that life doesn't have to follow a strict timeline. Reading, staying active, and talking with friends have become my go-to ways to manage stress, and I've learned to accept uncertainty instead of fighting against it. I don't know where I'm headed next, but I feel more at peace with not knowing than I ever have before. My family has always been a constant presence in my life, even if we don't always agree on things, and their support has given me the freedom to make my own choices without too much pressure. I also appreciate that I don't rely on social media or online communities for emotional support—I find comfort in real, face-to-face connections, and that's helped me stay grounded even when I've felt uncertain about my path. I don't have any major health issues, but I've been trying to take better care of myself in small ways—like eating more regularly, walking more, and being more present in my daily life. It's not always easy, but I've come to accept that consistency matters more than perfection. I feel like I'm on a path that's more intentional now, even if it's not the one I expected.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Nicholas Aguirre: In total, my household made around $1,800 in the past month, which is pretty much what I usually make. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover my rent, groceries, and the small things I enjoy—like buying a new book or grabbing coffee with a friend. I don't need much to be happy, and I think that's part of why I've been able to stay content with my current situation. I also set aside about $100 each month for savings or unexpected expenses, just in case. It's not a huge amount, but it gives me a sense of security, and I think that's enough for now.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Nicholas Aguirre: I've been working at the bookstore for almost four years now, since right after I graduated high school. It's been a long time, but I don't feel like I've been there forever. The benefits of the job aren't exactly traditional—there's no health insurance or paid vacation days, but I think that's part of what makes it work for me. I don't need a lot of structure or perks; I value the flexibility and the freedom to set my own schedule. I get a few days off each week, and I can take time off when I need to without too much hassle. The store owner is pretty understanding, and I've built a good relationship with her over the years. She's like a second mother to me in a way—she knows my habits, my preferences, and she gives me the space to be myself. I think the biggest benefit is the sense of community I feel there. It's not just a job; it's a place where I can connect with people who share my love for books and storytelling. That kind of connection is something I don't think you can buy with a fancy benefits package, and I'm really grateful for it.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Nicholas Aguirre: My relationships at work are pretty comfortable and familiar. The store owner, Ms. Harper, is like a second mother to me—she's been nothing but supportive since day one. She gives me a lot of freedom, which I really appreciate, and she's always been understanding if I need to take a day off or adjust my hours. As for my coworkers, we're all pretty laid-back, which fits with the vibe of the store. There's Jordan, who I mentioned before—he's been my friend for years, and we work well together. Then there's Clara, who's newer but has a great sense of humor and always knows how to lighten the mood. We don't have any major conflicts, and we all get along pretty well. I think it's because we all share a love for books and the kind of quiet, thoughtful environment the store offers. It's not a high-pressure job, and that makes it easier to build good relationships. I feel like I'm part of a small, close-knit team, and that makes the work feel more like a community effort than just a job.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Nicholas Aguirre: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's also flexible enough that I can adjust it when needed. I usually work the same days each week—Mondays, Wednesdays, Fridays, and Sundays—but the hours can vary depending on how busy the store is. Some days I might start at 2 p.m. and finish by 8 p.m., while on others, especially weekends, I might stay a bit later if there's a special event or a lot of customers. The store owner, Ms. Harper, trusts me to manage my own time, which I really appreciate. It gives me the freedom to take days off when I need to or to adjust my hours if something comes up. I think that flexibility is one of the things I value most about the job—it allows me to maintain a balance between work, my personal life, and the evening classes I've been taking. It's not perfect, but it works for me.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Nicholas Aguirre: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation. It's not extravagant, and I know I could be making more money if I took on a different kind of job, but I don't think I'd be any happier. What I value more than money is the freedom to make my own choices, to live on my own terms, and to have the time to do the things I enjoy—like reading, walking by the river, or taking those evening classes. I don't need a lot to be satisfied, and I think that's part of why I've been able to find peace with where I am. I know some people might look at my income and think I'm struggling, but I don't see it that way. I have a roof over my head, I can eat, I can save a little, and I have the flexibility to explore new things without feeling like I'm tied down by debt or a rigid schedule. I think that's a pretty good foundation to build from, even if it's not the most traditional path.

Going through the interview questions about my bills, savings, and work schedule made me realize how much I've come to value simplicity and consistency in my life. I used to worry about whether I was making enough money or if I was saving enough for the future, but now I see that my financial situation is more about stability than abundance. My bills don't fluctuate too much, which gives me a sense of control, and my savings, though small, provide me with a cushion that I can rely on. I don't need a lot to be happy, and I think that's why I've been able to find peace with my current income and lifestyle. My part-time job at the bookstore gives me the flexibility I need to balance work with my personal time and learning, and I'm grateful for that. I don't see myself changing much in the near future, but I'm content with where I am right now.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Nicholas Aguirre: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom was a high school teacher for over 20 years, and my dad worked in engineering before he retired a few years ago. They both had pretty stable jobs, which gave our family a sense of security. I remember seeing them both work hard, especially my mom—she was always grading papers or planning lessons late into the night. My dad was more hands-on with his work, but he was also pretty dedicated. I think their work ethic influenced me a lot, even if I didn't always follow the same path. I don't know if I would have made the same choices they did, but I respect the sacrifices they made to give me the opportunities I had. It's funny, looking back, because I used to think I wanted to be different from them, but now I see how much they shaped me, even if I didn't always realize it at the time.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Nicholas Aguirre: My mom was a high school teacher, and her most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and working closely with her students to help them succeed. She had a real passion for education, and I think that's why she stayed in the same school for so long. She was always the kind of teacher who stayed after class to help students who were struggling, and she made sure that every student felt seen and supported. My dad worked in engineering—he was involved in designing infrastructure projects, like roads and bridges. His most important duties were analyzing blueprints, working with teams to solve technical problems, and making sure that everything met safety and quality standards. He was pretty detail-oriented, and I remember him always saying that even the smallest mistake could have big consequences. Both of them had their own ways of being dedicated to their work, and I think that's something I've carried with me, even if I didn't end up following the same path as them.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Nicholas Aguirre: My mom worked for the local school district, and my dad was employed by a civil engineering firm that specialized in infrastructure projects. My mom's job was pretty much centered around teaching high school English and literature, and she also took on extra responsibilities like advising students and organizing school events. She was always passionate about her work, and I think that's why she stayed in the same school for so long. My dad, on the other hand, worked for a company that handled municipal projects—like designing and maintaining roads, bridges, and public buildings. He was pretty hands-on, spending a lot of time on-site or in meetings with other engineers and city officials. I remember him coming home with blueprints and maps spread out all over the table, trying to figure out the best way to solve a problem. Both of them had stable jobs that gave our family a good sense of security, and I think that's something I've always appreciated, even if I didn't always follow the same path they did.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Nicholas Aguirre: I hope that in a few years, I'm still living in a place that feels like home, maybe even the same neighborhood, but with a little more stability in my life. I don't know if I'll still be working at the bookstore, but I hope I'm doing something that brings me joy and keeps me connected to the things I love—like reading, learning, and being around people who share my interests. I'd like to have a little more financial security, maybe save enough to take a trip somewhere I've always wanted to go, or even take more classes and see where that leads me. I don't want to rush into anything, but I do hope I'm growing in some way, even if it's small. I think I'd also like to have more time for the people I care about, whether it's my parents, my friends, or maybe even someone I end up meeting along the way. I don't know what the future holds, but I hope it's something that feels meaningful, even if it's not what I expected.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Nicholas Aguirre: What I value the most in my life is the sense of independence I've built over the years, along with the simple things that bring me peace—like reading a good book, walking by the river, or just having a quiet evening at home. I also value the relationships I have, even if they're not always the most traditional. My parents have always given me the freedom to make my own choices, and I think that's something I really appreciate. I don't need a lot to be happy, but I do want to feel like I'm growing, even in small ways. I value learning, whether it's through books, classes, or just talking to someone I respect. And I value the stability of my current life—the fact that I don't have to worry about major financial stress or complicated responsibilities. It's not perfect, but it's mine, and I think that matters more than anything else.

Going through the interview questions about my work, relationships at the workplace, and the flexibility of my schedule made me realize how much I've come to appreciate the balance I have in my life. I've been working at the bookstore for almost four years, and while it's not a traditional job with all the typical benefits, it gives me the freedom and flexibility I need to live on my own terms. My relationships with my coworkers and manager are comfortable and familiar, which makes the job feel more like a community than just a place to earn money. I value the predictability of my schedule, even if it's not always perfect, because it allows me to maintain a sense of control over my time. I think I've been lucky to find a job that aligns with my values—freedom, simplicity, and connection—and I'm grateful for that. It's comforting to know that I can continue to grow and explore new things without feeling tied down by a rigid structure or overwhelming responsibilities.

Going through this complete interview and life story has given me a chance to look back and see how much of who I am today has been shaped by the choices I've made, the people I've known, and the quiet, steady path I've walked. I never imagined I'd end up where I am now—working at the bookstore, living in a quiet neighborhood, and taking evening classes at the community college—but looking back, I see how each step, even the ones that felt uncertain at the time, led me here. I've always valued independence, and I think that's what has defined my life the most. I didn't follow the traditional route of going to college right after high school, but I made a choice that felt right for me, and it gave me the freedom to grow on my own terms. I've learned that life doesn't have to be dramatic or fast-paced to be meaningful. It can be simple, steady, and full of small joys—like reading a good book, walking by the river, or having a quiet evening with a cup of coffee. I've also come to appreciate the support of my family, even if we don't always agree on everything. They've given me the space to figure things out, and that has been incredibly important. I don't know what the future holds, but I feel grounded in the present, and I'm okay with that. This reflection has reminded me that I'm not just a collection of events or decisions—I'm a person who has built a life that feels true to who I am, even if it's not what others might expect.
